newsitem.title: BELGIUM: High-tech imports boost EU trade deficit with NAFTA.
newsitem.headline: High-tech imports boost EU trade deficit with NAFTA.

text.p: Weighed down by an increase in imports of office machinery and high-tech products, the European Union recorded a $3.4 billion trade deficit with the North American Free Trade Area in 1995, according to latest figures.

The data, released by the European Union's statistical office Eurostat on Monday, showed EU imports from NAFTA -- which groups the United States, Canada and Mexico -- rose by 5.3 percent while exports fell 3.6 percent.
The 2.9 billion European currency unit (Ecu) trade deficit follows two years in which the 15-nation EU enjoyed surpluses with NAFTA of 7.4 billion Ecus in 1994 and 5.5 billion in 1993.
EU trade with NAFTA was concentrated in the manufacturing sector, Eurostat said, with over 78 percent of imports and 90 percent of exports.

NAFTA is the EU's most important regional trade partner, accounting for some 21 percent of all trade. The U.S., however, dominates the bloc with 18 percent of trade while Canada and Mexico have two and one percent respectively.
Eurostat said office machinery, computers and other high-tech imports registered the biggest growth in the EU, accounting for 12.7 billion Ecus and leading to a deficit of 8.4 billion Ecus.
Leading EU exports were road vehicles (worth 12.4 billion and leading to a 9 billion Ecu surplus) and specialised machinery.
Eurostat said Britain remained the biggest importer of NAFTA goods in the EU, while Germany was the biggest exporter.

Germany and Italy posted the biggest trade surpluses with the U.S. -- 11 billion and 5.8 billion Ecus respectively -- while Britain and the Netherlands had the biggest deficit with 7.3 billion Ecu each.
